item.title: Unfinished Reflection Bot
item.dc:creator: @qauters qauters
item.description:
@qauters wrote:

Mopman:

I’m not sure how much of that applies to the RS cheating community, where releasing something is not so much giving birth to an idea, but giving birth to ten thousand emails over the next year asking how to “run ur leet hax plz it says java not found and omg u suck”.

I started with my updater using PSB’s and Ollie’s updater. It’s a great way to learn how things are done when you see the code.
Except a lot of people at the cheating scene, only come to leech, not to learn. So releasing something usualy ends up with a lot of flames at you (from the noobs).
However I’m still eternal gratefull to psb and ollie for their work.

Read full topic

item.title: Unfinished Reflection Bot
item.dc:creator: @unlimitedorb unlimitedorb
item.description:
@unlimitedorb wrote:

“Bob” is a “look and don’t touch”, albeit brilliant, person. Eventually he has some time on his hands to surf to a forum in order to view current hot topics in a community that he cares for (though he may be unwilling to admit it.) Seeing a conversation that he believes to be a worthy cause he makes a seemingly innocuos post to influence the direction the conversation is headed toward. Though his argument is wonderfully put, there is something even more special in his post than the words that he painstakingly typed out. Beyond the words, there is the revival of a new idea: footnotes. The application of something so obvious yet helpful seems to have slipped through the cracks of the community. Eventually “Bob” comes back to see that many of the posts after his own contain footnotes, and as a result, “Bob” is able to understand what other people are saying with far more clarity. It seems that both parties have benefited: Bob AND the community.

I personally believe that many of the arguments presented thus far are fundamentally flawed in that they are based on the idea that the said person releasing code is doing it out of the kindness of his/her heart, and can benefit no longer once the code is released publicly.

Releasing code is an investment…plain and simple. If one releases code to a community, they are not only encouraging people that benefit from the code to act in the same manner, but they are also guiding the community toward their idea of perfection. The problem is that one person’s idea of perfection can conflict with another person’s idea of perfection. In some cases, they can combine to form an entirely new (and far stronger) reflection of perfection (ultimately, this is the investment that I speak of).

By releasing code to the masses, one can find that there are two outcomes: the release is a total flop and nobody learns from it, or a special few are able to rise above the general masses and see the code for what it truly is…an investment in their future. When all is said and done, those few in the latter case are able to break out of the norm, destroy circular reasoning, and keep the community fresh with new ideas. Giving birth to new life in the form of ideas is a strenuous task when it really comes down to it, but if even one of those baby ideas grows up into an adult and gives birth to new baby ideas then it was all worth it; everybody can learn something new.

Philosophical
Guys, if you have ever wanted to give birth, then releasing your code is probably one of the closest things you can get to doing it. So go ahead and give birth, some of your babies are bound to die, but there’s a chance that a few will survive and follow in your footsteps…

^Has something like that ever been said before? Because that came off the top of my head haha.

Read full topic

item.title: Unfinished Reflection Bot
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

Exception:

Along with knowledge whoring/hording comes a complete elitist attitude. Which is perfectly fine when the only people who would ever benefit from your work are unappreciative 11 year olds with mental deficiencies (MoparScape.org). I personally believe that if somebody is willing to learn from and appreciate code somebody else has written, then it should be released. Perhaps not released to everybody, so the aforementioned 11 year olds will be none the wiser, or perhaps not in it’s whole form, so it wouldn’t be outright stolen.

The idea behind releasing code to the public is that the public gets the code, not just a group of people who you wish to have the code. I know moparscapers for the large part are genuine idiots who live in a bubble-wrapped world of copy and paste, but not so long ago[sup]1[/sup] the cheating scene revolved around copy and paste tutorials on modifying the client. I must admit that even I used these tutorials, though unlike [some] others, I made a point to find out why something worked.

There are many, much better ways to learn as opposed to learning by reading code tooled to suit runescape cheating. There are essentially two things that you will have a problem with and need to “learn” how to overcome them, what you want to do and how you will go about it. Though looking at code written by other people may help you learn both these things, a self-driven person with a brain will be able to sketch out what they want to achieve and then learn whichever tools he is using in order to complete this goal. If you write your own code, you will (should…) know exactly what is happening and why, if you just leech someone else’s and don’t understand it, chances are that you will just accept the fact that it works and never give it a second thought until it breaks.

One of my bigger gripes with this community is that you all seem to believe that releasing “stuff” will magically solve everything and make the world a happy place. It will not, purely for the fact that many of the people bleating and making a fuss that code should be released wouldn’t understand it even if it were perfectly documented. That said, people who make a fuss when they release code[sup]2[/sup] more often than not release something poorly designed/written/commented and then proceed to claim that it is something that it is not.

  1. A relatively short time anyway, perhaps 5 years ago.
  2. You all know who I mean. I have also been guilty of this.

ps: all the cool kids were doing it

Read full topic

item.title: Unfinished Reflection Bot
item.dc:creator: @semaphore semaphore
item.description:
@semaphore wrote:


I found myself with long run-on sentences that really took away from what I was trying to say when I had inlined my ‘footnotes’. The only solutions I could think of were superscripts.

As far as the elitist attitude goes I agree with you. It sucks. But that is precisely why I did the research I did. I wanted to know what the supposed elitists knew. And now, I do.

Another interesting pattern I’ve seen is that the term elitism is used along with knowledge whoring. Elitism seems to be just a term used on someone that may take a jab at someone else making a stupid/ignorant/wrong statement. Further, the person making the jab seems to be someone that could answer the questions just cba to do so.

I know I’m considered to be in the group of elitists for whatever valid or invalid reasons. The people to whom I have shared information seem to refrain from that term but those to whom I have snubbed seem to embrace it. I see a pattern.

“If we don’t get spoon fed by you and you mock us, you are an elitist and we hates you”.

So be it. Instead of complaining, read my sig and then learn to read code.

Read full topic

Maybe I should start using footnotes in my posts ;\

item.title: Unfinished Reflection Bot
item.dc:creator: @semaphore semaphore
item.description:
@semaphore wrote:

@Mopman: Well put. I loved the last line

It’s interesting that the people that have pushed me to open my source and accused me of information whoring are the ones that would benefit most from my acquiescing. I think the case can be made that the ones that scream the loudest for opening someone else’s source, are likely the ones that would gain the most. Tell me, what does the developer that actually wrote the code really gain? Fame? Respect? Nothing. How absolutely typical… While it’s nice to have your ego stroked, it sure as hell doesn’t pay the bills and put food on the table[sup]1[/sup]. While some code is written for the pure love of the craft, let’s be real, much code is written to line the pockets so you can code another day.

I’ve had many conversations with other individuals that know just about everything about the rs client. (Most are simply not active here… wonder why…). Every one of them has been told, in one way or another, that they should open their source for the good of the community. Bull. If wL had released his real server and his completely renamed client, it would have been far more information than the community needed. It was completely his prerogative to decide not to give his code to the community at large.

I believe there are times and places for open source and closed source. Like Mopman eloquently put,

[quote=“Mopman, post:23, topic:178224”]…
At the end of the day, open source is not about changing the world. It is not about forcing anyone to do anything they don’t want to do. It is about having the source code to your applications available to change how you wish, enabling personal customisation and the easy collaboration of developers. That is it.
…[/quote]

I agree that if you plan on giving something away for free, you sure as hell should provide the code so that others can learn from it. Licensing under that model, is more, I think, to protect the code from being abused and also to allow the original writer to get his/her/their ego(s) stroked every so often.

If my system was one that was going to go out to the public freely, I wouldn’t have a problem gpl’ing it. That’s just it, I have no intentions to do so. Most of my code is completely closed source. Most of the information behind it is also. Some may call it knowledge whoring[sup]2[/sup] but I disagree. If someone came to a knowledge of something on their own, why should the be disparaged just because they don’t feel like spoon feeding anyone that comes after them? Sounds like something kids do when something ‘gets too hard’ and they want someone to give them the answer; whining.

[sup]1[/sup]: Yes, I know first hand that having a good coding reputation can land you all kinds of fantastic consulting jobs it is more an exception than the rule.
[sup]2[/sup]: A malapropism if you ask me as it has nothing to do with prostituting knowledge. Perhaps knowledge hording would have been more appropriate

Read full topic

item.title: Unfinished Reflection Bot
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Yakman, while I respect you as a developer and a poster - it’s your “open source is the solution to all problems” attitude that introduces many problems to the FOSS world, in my opinion, not least by making everyone think that we are all stark raving mad communist uber-hippies who are all fighting to steal their personal freedoms one badly written C++ application at a time.

Because you use this development model, every single developer in the world should be forced to use it to, by you rereleasing their product under a different license illegally (that is essentially what “leaking” is, no?) This is freedom?

I use FOSS. I use a lot of FOSS, from my operating system to my window manager to 90% of my applications. Do I completely denounce commercial software? No. I use commercial software, shit, I have written closed-source commercial software.

At the end of the day, open source is not about changing the world. It is not about forcing anyone to do anything they don’t want to do. It is about having the source code to your applications available to change how you wish, enabling personal customisation and the easy collaboration of developers. That is it. It’s a development model, not a poor way for the laymen to learn about Communism. (That said, it has nothing to do with Communism anyway, the metaphor is very very loose).

Right this is absurdly ranty, so, summary time: Leaking shit is wrong, whether you hide behind the “i believe in open source!” banner or not.

Read full topic

I want to learn about stuff, and if leaked code helps me do that, then so be it. I don’t care what frank_ or anyone else thinks of me because of it.[/quote]

i love how you seem to love open source, though open source more often than not involves licensing and giving credit where it is due, it appears that you have no problem with theft of intellectual property. your apparent hypocrisy and stupidity is unrivaled

item.title: Unfinished Reflection Bot
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

if the application is released, it should be allowed to be reused, provided of course that you give thanks for it and not claim to have written the code yourself.

if it is leaked, however, anyone who uses it should probably ask the author if it is alright to use. leaked code is often incomplete and might reflect badly on the programming habits of the authors.

that said, purposely leaking other people’s work is pathetic and anyone who requests leaked code should be shunned

Read full topic

item.title: Unfinished Reflection Bot
item.dc:creator: @Taios Taios
item.description:
@Taios wrote:

[quote=“yakman, post:16, topic:178224”]by the way, im sorry shangtsung1, we appear to have off-topic’d your thread.

Of course you wouldn’t regret it, you didn’t make it.

yes, I’m sorry, i didn’t see it that way, i understand how you would feel…
but its quite incomplete, there no way you can auto with it, it wont even compile because of a lot of missing stuff, and i don’t think theres is no main() method anywhere.
however, the stuff that is included is very interesting, i liked the way you can pause scripts a lot, i think its much better then the return-style scripting.
there are no .svn files, someone used svn export probably.
i thought you knew about this leakage though
as for who sent it to me, this person wasn’t an Arga developer, and i assumed it was quite well known, and that it had changed hands quite a lot before it go to me. i don’t know where this source got it from.

here is a list of everything in that directory if you want to know, (with unix dir command)

user$dir -aRC

.:
.   ARGA-zeta.zip  build.xml  gameCache.jar  out.pdb     pathdbs  rel      update.cfg     zetacorner.bmp
..  bin            Engines    lib            pathdb.dat  Randoms  Scripts  worldlist.xml

./bin:
.  ..

./Engines:
.  ..  DefaultEngine

./Engines/DefaultEngine:
.   config.xml             DefaultEngine.java     DefaultMethods.java              DefaultRandom.java  DefaultScriptStoppedException.java
..  DefaultConstants.java  DefaultGUIScript.java  DefaultRandomCheckerThread.java  DefaultScript.java

./lib:
.  ..  bcel-5.2.jar

./pathdbs:
.              2904,3440.dat  2944,3320.dat  2984,3200.dat  3048,3184.dat  3088,3464.dat  3160,3336.dat  3192,3128.dat  3240,3360.dat
..             2912,3264.dat  2952,3280.dat  2992,3392.dat  3048,3464.dat  3096,3152.dat  3168,3168.dat  3192,3208.dat  3248,3072.dat
2872,3208.dat  2912,3360.dat  2960,3128.dat  3008,3248.dat  3064,3104.dat  3112,3112.dat  3168,3464.dat  3208,3464.dat  3248,3152.dat
2880,3168.dat  2920,3160.dat  2960,3200.dat  3024,3304.dat  3064,3144.dat  3112,3376.dat  3176,3168.dat  3216,3288.dat  3248,3192.dat
2880,3248.dat  2928,3448.dat  2968,3432.dat  3032,3344.dat  3080,3272.dat  3128,3192.dat  3176,3296.dat  3216,3376.dat  3248,3440.dat
2888,3304.dat  2936,3368.dat  2968,3472.dat  3032,3368.dat  3088,3184.dat  3152,3120.dat  3176,3376.dat  3224,3280.dat  3264,3272.dat
2896,3400.dat  2944,3240.dat  2976,3160.dat  3032,3424.dat  3088,3288.dat  3152,3376.dat  3184,3248.dat  3232,3400.dat

./Randoms:
.  ..

./rel:
.  ..  releasebuild.xml

./Scripts:
.                      GetAnimations.java  LoggedInScript.java  NPCScanner.java    PathBitmapper.java       PathDrawer.java
..                     InterfaceInfo.java  MenuOptioner.java    ObjectDumper.java  PathBitmapperV2.java     PathMerger.java
BasicWorldWalker.java  InvDumper.java      MyPos.java           OmniMiner.java     PathDatabaseDumper.java  PlayerScanner.java

as for my policy of leaking, i understand why sometimes is better not to be leaked, if it were to be “fixed” by an authority (jagex),
also, if its in development, like early alpha or something
but if someone would really help teach the community, that should be leaked in my opinion.

like with leaking bots that work with bytecode, there are quite a few publicly released anyway, and people can just read what other people say, its not very difficult to learn about that with current resources.[/quote]

We do intend to release it later on and open source as before.
If we decide to not work on the project anymore, it would be highly likely that we released it.

Read full topic

item.title: Unfinished Reflection Bot
item.dc:creator: @Taios Taios
item.description:
@Taios wrote:

I understand when code is released you have little control of it.
What i was saying is you should really respect the developer and their wishes. If they wished it to be removed for whatever reason, it should. Like ruler should have respected our wishes that he not try and somewhat use arga in his bot. He didn’t use the code directly but he ignored our repeated ‘let us develope our bot and leave us alone’. he got the asshole bout this loler.

As i hope you should know, I am all for open source being that i was in a team which released the first open source public BCEL bot.

I am however curious as to how you managed to get it because as far as i know we very much limited svn access(our passes are also 15 chars + long and i don’t even know my pass off by heart). Of course you wouldn’t regret it, you didn’t make it lol.
Besides it would/will be open source like the old arga when released(no idea when because i have been unavailable as developer for 4-5 months now).

Read full topic
